STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
January 8, 2025
Stephanie Rae Sears
Methodist Children's Home Society
26645 W 6 Mile Rd
Detroit, MI, 48240-2319
Re: License #: CB820201295
SI #: 2025SIC0000065
Dear Stephanie Rae Sears:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
AMENDED
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000065
Special Investigation Intake Date: October 29, 2024
License #: CB820201295
Licensee Group Organization: Methodist Children's Home Society
Licensee Designee: Kevin M Roach
Chief Administrator: Stephanie Rae Sears
Agency Name: Methodist Children's Home Society
Agency Address: 26645 W 6 Mile Rd
Detroit, MI 48240-2319
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 01/31/2025
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
10/29/2024 Email Special Investigation Initiation
10/29/2024 Email Special Investigation Initiation
10/30/2024 Email Documentation received or sent

11/26/2024 Email Documentation received or sent
1/7/2024 Video Conference Exit Conference
1

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Medical, dental and mental health care
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12507
Section • (1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent
Description living receives any needed medical, dental, and mental
health care as required in R 400.12413. Medical, dental,
and mental health care provided must be documented in
the youth's record.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 10/18/24, there was an incident at school which required youth
to go to the hospital. No staff could be reached, and the school
accompanied the youth. Staff arrived two hours later. Youth was
supposed to have the staples removed within 5 days and staff did
not comply with this even though they were aware. Youth
currently still has the staples in their head even though they
should have been removed by 10/25/24.
Youth is prescribed medication for various diagnosis's and there
have been multiple occasions where medication was delayed by a
day or more.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
All interviews were completed along with DHHS Worker.
Youth A was interviewed in person at the Independent Living
home in which he lives on 10/30/2024. Youth A reported being
shoved into a wall at school during an argument with a peer on
10/18/2024. Youth A reported school staff attempted to contact
Foster Care Worker 1, but they were unable to reach her, so they
called an ambulance. Since Youth A is a minor, an adult had to
accompany him in the ambulance, so someone from the school
rode with Youth A. Youth A stated he was at the emergency room
for approximately 30-minutes before Foster Care Worker 2,
arrived at the hospital. Youth A reported receiving 4 staples in has
head after which he was given ibuprofen. He stated the doctor told
him to either come back to the emergency room or go to any
doctor or urgent care to have the staples removed after 5 days.
Youth A reported not having been given any discharge paperwork,
nor seeing anyone else get the paperwork.
2

Youth A reported youth are not allowed to make their own medical
appointments and must be transported by staff to those
appointments. Youth A reported being taken to urgent care by
Foster Care Worker 1 on10/22/2024 due to Youth A having
difficulty breathing for which Youth A was given antibiotics. The
following day, Youth A contacted Foster Care Worker 1 to let her
know it had been 5 days since the staples were administered, so it
was time to have them removed. Foster Care Worker 1 told Youth
A she was off work that day but would make an appointment for
Youth A to have the staples removed. Foster Care Worker 1 told
Youth A she tried to call him back about an appointment, but
Youth A was asleep. Youth A didn’t remember this, but stated he
was sick, so it was possible. He stated he was worried about the
staples being in his head to long. Seven days later, Youth A was
told by staff at the home where he is living to not go to school and
to go to Foster Care Worker 1’s office. Foster Care Worker 1 told
Youth A he had an appointment to get the staples removed, which
was the first time Youth A was told of the appointment. The doctor
who removed the staples stated the wound was healing well and
everything looked good.
Youth A also expressed concern with his medication
administration. He reported he takes 3 medications, which are
comprised of 6 pills per day. He stated there have been three
occasions since he came to the independent living home in which
he was completely out of at least one of his medications. Youth A
stated his medication is stored in a medication room at the home
and his pills are popped from a bubble pack into a paper cup by
staff, so he has no way of knowing how many pills are left. He
stated on 10/27/2024, he was only given one of his medications
and was told he had run out of the other two. He reported only
being given that one medication on the 27th and 28th but receiving
all three again on the 29th. Youth A stated he was feeling
impulsive, emotional, and tingly and that his OCD symptoms
worsened while he was out of his medication. Youth A stated the
previous two times he ran out of medications it was only one
medication and only for one day each time.
Director 1, who is the director of all transitional living programs at
the agency was interviewed in person on 10/30/2204. He reported
on the day Youth A was injured at school, Foster Care Worker 1
was in a court hearing, so Foster Care Worker 2 went to the
hospital to be with Youth A. He reported Director 2 supervises the
foster care workers, so she would have additional information
about that incident.
3

Director 1 stated there have been three times Youth A has not had
all of his medication. He reported the agency uses a system called
“Pharma Script” that ensures medications are refilled and
delivered automatically. When Youth A’s medication was out on
Sunday, Pharma Script was closed and could not be contacted
and when they were contacted the following Monday, they
apologized. He stated the previous times Youth A ran out of
medication it was because Youth A received the text notifications
about the refills, so the staff were not aware. He stated this has
only ever happened to Youth A and they are now going to gauge if
medications are getting low so they can avoid this happening
again.
Director 2 who is the director of foster care services was
interviewed in person on 10/30/2024. She reported being
contacted on 10/18/2024 and informed of the incident at school
with Youth A, but did not recall who contacted her. She stated
Foster Care Worker 1 was in court, so she contacted Foster Care
Worker 2 to fill in at the hospital with Youth A. Director 2 stated
Foster Care Worker 2 kept in contact with her to let her know what
was going on and that Youth A got 4 staples in his head. Foster
Care Worker 2 was given Youth A’s discharge paperwork which
was then given to Director 2. She stated the paperwork only
stated the staples needed to be removed, but there was no
timeframe in the paperwork. She stated she was told verbally the
staples had to be removed after approximately a week by Foster
Care Worker 2. Director 2 stated it came to her attention this week
that Youth A wanted the staples out ASAP, so she spoke to Foster
Care Worker 1 who was in the process of making an appointment.
Director 2 reported she does not know how specifically the staff at
the agency became aware of Youth A’s concern about the staples
nor did she know why it took so long for the staples to get
removed, but she knows they were removed yesterday.
Director 2 reported each youth’s assigned foster care worker
takes them to their medical appointments. A computer system
keeps track of the medications and automatically refills and
delivers when they are low. Staff and supervisors of the home are
responsible for checking medications to ensure they do not run
out. The staff will typically let foster care workers know if the
medications are running low.
Foster Care Worker 1 was interviewed in person on 10/30/2024.
She reported she was in court on 10/18/2024 after which she
received a call from Foster Care Worker 2 with photos of the
staples in Youth A’s head. She stated she was not given the
4

discharge paperwork initially but when eventually provided with
them, she saw there was no specific timeframe in which to bring
Youth A to have the staples removed. She reported Youth A never
gave her a timeframe either. She stated she made a “judgment”
that the staples should be removed in 7-10 days. Foster Care
Worker 1 stated it is her responsibility to make medical
appointments for the youths and to make sure they get their
medical care. She stated she called the hospital on 10/25/2024 to
ask if the staples needed to be removed by the hospital, but was
told it could be done by any doctor. She did not ask if there was
timeframe in which they should be removed. She stated she
brought Youth A to urgent care on 10/22/2024 because he was
sick. That doctor looked at the staples while he was there and said
the injury was healing well. She stated she did not ask that doctor
when the staples should be removed as she felt Youth A’s illness
was more important at that point. She reported, in her personal
experience as a previous Certified Nursing Assistant as well as
with her own family, the staples should be removed in 7-10 days,
so she planned to make an appointment with Youth A's primary
medical provider within that timeframe. She stated she told Youth
A on 10/22/2024 not to worry because she would make an
appointment for the staples to be removed. She reported having
made an appointment on 10/25/2024 after which the staples were
removed 10/29/2024. The doctor who removed the staples stated
the incision looked good and there were no concerns. She denied
making the appointment as a result of the complaint resulting in
this allegation.
Regarding Youth A’s medication, Foster Care Worker 1 reported
she brings youths to their psychiatrist appointments and the doctor
will call in prescriptions to the pharmacy. The pharmacy delivers
the medications to the agency. If medications do not arrive, Foster
Care Worker 1 will call the doctor and pharmacy. She stated
Youth A’s last medication review was on 10/8/2024 after which all
his medications were called in, but she believed the pharmacy did
not fill all of the medications because he ran out. She stated Youth
A did not call her about his missing medication, but someone
called her on Monday to let her know Youth A was out of his
medications. She stated Youth A had missed medication in the
past because they were sent to the wrong pharmacy and the only
person who received the notification was Youth A.
Independent living Plus Supervisor was interviewed in person
on 10/30/2024. She reported receiving a call from Youth A’s
school on 10/18/2024 about the incident with Youth A and a peer.
She stated she was told he needed stitches, and someone had to
5

ride to the hospital with him in an ambulance. Independent Living
Plus Supervisor contacted Foster Care Worker 2 because Foster
Care Worker 1 was in court. Foster Care Worker 2 was out with
some of the youths in the community, so he was going to contact
his supervisor. When Youth A returned to the home, Independent
Living Plus Supervisor viewed his discharge paperwork which
indicated to keep the wound clean. She did not see anything on
the paperwork about a timeframe for the staples to be removed.
Independent Living Plus Supervisor reported youth medication
distribution is documented in a computer system. The system
doesn’t notify staff if medications are running out. If the staff notice
something is getting low, they should contact Independent Living
Plus Supervisor. No one told Independent Living Plus Supervisor
Youth A’s medications were getting low. She stated this was an
oversight and Independent Living Plus Supervisor’s responsibility.
She stated, moving forward, midnight staff will check medications
and call the assigned foster care worker if a youth has 5 pills or
less. Additionally, Independent Living Plus Supervisor will check
the medications weekly to ensure they do not run out.
Foster Care Worker 2 was interviewed via video conferencing on
11/15/2024. He reported he was transporting a youth from an
appointment when Independent Living Plus Supervisor called him
and said Youth A was going to the hospital for a head injury and
Foster Care Worker 1 was in court. Foster Care Worker 2 stated
there was some confusion because the school had indicated they
would wait for Foster Care Worker 2 to arrive before leaving with
Youth A then Independent Living Plus Supervisor called back and
said Youth A was already on the way to the hospital. Foster Care
Worker 2 dropped off the youth he was transporting then went to
the hospital where he met Youth A and a school staff member.
Foster Care Worker 2 stated he stayed with Youth A while the
staples were administered and the doctor said to bring Youth A in
to have the staples removed in a week. Foster Care Worker 2
stated he believed a week to mean 7 days. He stated the doctor
never specified a 5-day timeframe and he is unsure where that
timeframe came from. Foster Care Worker stated he remained in
touch with Director 2 while at the hospital but doesn’t remember if
he told her when the staples needed to be removed.
When Foster Care Worker 2 dropped Youth A off at the home, he
told Independent Living Plus Supervisor the staples needed to be
removed in about a week and that Youth A shouldn’t work. Foster
Care Worker 2 stated Foster Care Worker 1 would have been
responsible for making the appointment for the staples to be
6

removed. Foster Care Worker 2 stated he is now Youth A’s
assigned worker, but he does not know why there was a switch.
Foster Care Worker 2 reported he has never experienced any
issues with the youths on his caseload receiving their medications.
During a conversation with MDHHS Worker via video
conferencing on 11/15/2024, she reported speaking to the
receptionist at the medical facility where Youth A’s staples were
removed. The receptionist reported the appointment was not
made on 10/25/2024, rather it was made after 3:00PM on
10/28/2024, 10 days after the staples were administered. The
staples were removed during the next available appointment,
which was the following day, 10/29/2024. MDHHS Worker also
spoke to the emergency room doctor who administered the
staples who reviewed his notes which stated the direction he gave
to Youth A was to return to have the staples removed in 5 days.
School Counselor was interviewed by phone on 12/17/2024.
MDHHS Worker was not present for the interview. School
Counselor reported being with Youth A at the hospital when the
staples were applied to his head injury. She was in the room with
Youth A when the resident physician told Youth A to return to
have the staples removed in 4-5 days. School Counselor stated
the attending physician was not present when that instruction was
given.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
- 10/18/2024 After visit summary documenting Youth A was
diagnosed with a head injury and scalp laceration and to
follow up for suture removal
- 10/22/2024 Urgent care summary documenting Youth A
was treated for cough and chest congestion
- The agency Transitional Living Program Handbook Medical
Policy which states the Foster Care Case Manager is
responsible for scheduling appointments, arranging for
transportation and assisting the youth in medical needs.
- MDHHS Worker’s report documenting no findings.
Analysis The agency is found in violation of providing for needed medical
care of Youth A as Foster Care Worker 1 and Director 2 reported
Foster Care Worker 1 is responsible for making all of Youth A’s
medical appointments and transporting Youth A to those
appointments; however, Foster Care Worker 1 did not follow-up
after Youth A received staples in his head as to when the doctor
recommended the staples be removed, rather she reported having
used her own judgment that the staples should be removed after
7

7-10 days. Foster Care Worker 1 did not make an appointment 5
days after the staples were administered when asked to do so by
Youth A who informed Foster Care Worker 1, he was given this
timeframe by the doctor. Additionally, Foster Care Worker 2 and
Director 2 believed the staples were to be removed after a week.
Despite all of these factors, the staples were removed after 11
days.
The agency is also found in violation as Youth A missed some of
his medication due to two of his medications running out. The
agency requires all youths’ medication be stored in a locked
medication room and be administered by staff members;
therefore, it is the agency’s responsibility to ensure the youths do
not run out of their medication.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Eligibility requirements
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12504
Section • (1) An agency shall document the rationale for selection of
Description independent living as the most appropriate placement for
the youth.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation During the course of this investigation, concerns related to the
appropriateness of the youths for Independent Living placements
were raised related to the level of care and supervision needed.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Youth A was interviewed on 10/30/2024 in person. During the
interview, Youth A reported the following:
- Youth A believes youths were not allowed to be in the
home without staff, so they didn’t hurt themselves or others.
- Youths must ask for sharps from staff, such as knives when
prepping food.
- There is a youth in the home with significant cognitive
delays.
- There is a youth in the home who engages in coprophagia.
Director 1, who is the Director of all transitional living programs
was interviewed on 10/30/2024. Director 1 reported the following:
8

- Youths are not allowed to be in the home without a staff
member.
- For safety reasons, the agency wants eyes on the youths at
all times.
Director 1 stated the program was being operated under a child
caring institution license. During a meeting held 1/7/2025 via video
conferencing, Methodist Children’s Home Society felt this
statement was misrepresented and asked it to be amended to
clarify the interaction. Director 1 stated he meant the agency has a
CCI license, but didn’t mean the ILP program was operated under
that license.
Director 2, who is the Director of all Foster Care, Independent
Living, and Unaccompanied Refugee Minor programs was
interviewed on 10/30/2024. Director 2 reported the following:
- The ILP homes are staffed 24/7 and a staff must be in the
home with youths.
A phone call was held with Senior Director of Child Welfare on
11/1/2024. When informed there were concerns some of the
youths in the home might not be appropriate for an independent
living program as it sounds as if they need a level of care and
supervision provided by a child caring institution, she responded
some youths are referred to the program because they are leaving
residential and cannot go to a foster home or because there are
no other placement options. She stated the youths they receive
referrals for Independent Living Plus are very different than the
youths they used to receive, and they come with higher needs.
Foster Care Worker 2 was interviewed via video conferencing on
11/15/2024. He reported he has eleven youths on his caseload,
and they all have different needs and progress through the
program at different levels. He stated the youths on his caseload
all demonstrate the capability of living independently.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
The following documents were reviewed for the youths living in the
same cottage as Youth A:
Methodist Children’s Society Independent Living Plus Referral
Forms. These forms document the reason for the referral as well
as the youth’s level of independent living skills.
- Youth A referred due to age and high level of
independent living skills.
9

- Youth B referred due to APPLA status and 30-day
notice from caregiver, able to complete daily living
skills.
- Youth C referred due to statewide search resulting in
no placement options, can cook, clean and do
laundry.
- Youth D referred due to pending removal from
home, unknown if he exhibits self-sufficiency.
- Youth E referred due to APPLA status and readiness
for IL.
- Youth F referred due to placement needed, unknown
self-sufficiency.
- Youth G referred due to APPLA status and
readiness for IL.
- Youth H referred due to failed adoption.
- Youth I referred due to APPLA transition from Child
Caring Institution, history of emergency intervention
for self-harm.
- Youth J referred due to sexual abuse allegations
against siblings, elderly parents who have exhausted
their parental remedies regarding how to care
for/discipline him.
Methodist Children’s Society Independent Living Plus Interview
Forms. These forms consist, in part, of yes/no questions. The form
states if the response is “no” to an answer, the youth is not eligible
for the program. Three of the youths answered “no” to one
question each
- Youth E - No to not having criminal charges within
the past 12 months, on probation for 2023 criminal
sexual conduct. Approval/denial not completed.
- Youth G – No to living substance free lifestyle for
past 6 months, vaped and used prescription
medications 3 months ago. Approved
- Youth I – No to living substance free lifestyle for past
6 months, receiving substance abuse treatment,
vaped 4 months ago. Approved
Case Service Plans documenting youths’ progress. Of the nine
youths reviewed, information about the youth’s life skills ability as
well as participation in the program could be located in five
records.
- Youth C Updated Service Plan completed 3/27/24,
prior to ILP placement documented concerns with
Youth C’s ability to care for himself as well as his
10

aggressive behavior. No current service plan
available for review.
- Youth D Updated Service Plan completed 10/8/2024
documented participation and progress with
independent living skills.
- Youth H Updated Service Plan completed 9/19/24,
prior to ILP placement documented participation and
progress with independent living skills.
- Youth I Updated Service Plan completed 5/17/2024,
prior to ILP placement, documented concerns in
youth’s previous IL placement including stealing,
AWOLP, failure to follow rules/comply with program.
No current service plan available to review.
- Youth J Initial Service Plan completed 6/21/2024
cannot be generated/viewed. No current updated
service plan to review.
Analysis The agency is found in violation of documenting the rationale for
selection of independent living as the most appropriate placement
for the youth based on the lack of information in the case records.
Referral forms for the youth in the program do not provide
rationale for Youth D, Youth F, Youth H, Youth I and Youth J.
Interview forms for Youth E, Youth G, and Youth I all indicate they
answered one question each that would make them ineligible for
the program based on the agency’s own criteria for eligibility.
Additionally, service plans for Youth C and Youth I documented
concerns with their ability to live independently as well as to follow
program expectations.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Independent living record
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12509
Section • (3) The case record must contain all the following
Description information and documentation, which must be recorded
within 30 calendar days after placement in independent
living and updated at least once every 90 calendar days:
• (o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R
400.12420. If the youth have biological children, the
service plan must address the living arrangement for
the child or children, visitation/parenting time with
11

the youth's biological children or a clear explanation
why this is not possible or appropriate.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation During review of case record documentation during the course of
this investigation, it was discovered the records do not contain
service plans completed as required.
Investigation DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
The following documents were reviewed for the youths living in the
same cottage as Youth A:
• Initial Service Plans due since Methodist Children’s Society
assumed case responsibility:
o Youth F due 7/31/2024, in progress
• Updated Service Plans due since Methodist Children’s
Society assumed case responsibility:
o Youth A due 10/9/24, in progress
o Youth B due 10/8/2024, in progress
o Youth C due 9/15/2024, in progress
o Youth D due 10/7/2024, done 10/8/2024
o Youth E due 10/23/2024, in progress
o Youth G due 11/27/2024, in progress
o Youth H due 8/30/2024, done 9/19/2024
o Youth I due 11/13/2024, done 11/14/2024
o Youth J due 9/19/2024, in progress
Analysis Violation is established as none of the youth records reviewed
contained service plans completed, as required. Of the ten
records reviewed, three contained service plans completed past
their due dates and seven did not have current service plans
completed despite having due dates in September, October, and
November of 2024.
Conclusion REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Dated 3/1/2024, CAP Approved 3/22/2024
Renewal Dated 1/13/2023, CAP Approved1/31/2023
12

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
January 8, 2025
______________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
January 8, 2025

13
